Relative Chow stability and optimal weights

Carl Tipler UniversitÃ© de Bretagne Occidentale, 6, avenue Victor Le Gorgeu, 29238 Brest Cedex 3 France carl.tipler@univ-brest.fr
Abstract.

For a polarized KÃ¤hler manifold (X,L)ğ‘‹ğ¿(X,L), we show the equivalence between relative balanced embeddings introduced by Mabuchi and Ïƒğœ\sigma-balanced embeddings introduced by Sano, answering a question of Hashimoto. We give a GIT characterization of the existence of a Ïƒğœ\sigma-balanced embedding, and relate the optimal weight Ïƒğœ\sigma to the action of Aut0â€‹(X,L)subscriptAut0ğ‘‹ğ¿\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L) on the Chow line of (X,L)ğ‘‹ğ¿(X,L).

1. Introduction

By definition [2], an extremal KÃ¤hler metric on a polarized KÃ¤hler manifold (X,L)ğ‘‹ğ¿(X,L) is a critical point of the Calabi functional, which assigns to each KÃ¤hler metric in c1â€‹(L)subscriptğ‘1ğ¿c_{1}(L) the L2superscriptğ¿2L^{2}-norm of its scalar curvature. Constant scalar curvature KÃ¤hler metrics (cscK for short) are special examples of extremal metrics. Initially stated for cscK metrics, the Yau-Tian-Donaldson conjecture, refined by SzÃ©kelyhidi [23], predicts that the existence of an extremal KÃ¤hler metric on a given polarized KÃ¤hler manifold (X,L)ğ‘‹ğ¿(X,L) should be equivalent to a relative GIT stability notion of (X,L)ğ‘‹ğ¿(X,L). This conjecture should be seen as an infinite dimensional Kempf-Ness correspondence.

In [4], Donaldson introduced a finite dimensional approximation to this Kempf-Ness correspondence, via quantization. Let Aut0â€‹(X,L)subscriptAut0ğ‘‹ğ¿\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L) be the automophism group of (X,L)ğ‘‹ğ¿(X,L) modulo the â„‚âˆ—superscriptâ„‚\mathbb{C}^{*}-action by rotation on the fibers of Lğ¿L. If this group is discrete, cscK metrics can be approximated by a sequence of balanced metrics. Balanced metrics are particular KÃ¤hler metrics induced by projective embeddings Xâ†ªâ„™â€‹(Hâ€‹(X,Lk)âˆ—)â†ªğ‘‹â„™ğ»superscriptğ‘‹superscriptğ¿ğ‘˜X\hookrightarrow\mathbb{P}(H(X,L^{k})^{*}). They appear as zeros of a finite dimensional moment map, and their existence correspond to the Chow stability of (X,Lk)ğ‘‹superscriptğ¿ğ‘˜(X,L^{k}) [26, 12, 18, 19]. From the general theory of moment maps, balanced metrics satisfy a unicity property. As a corollary, one obtains uniqueness of a cscK metric in c1â€‹(L)subscriptğ‘1ğ¿c_{1}(L) under the assumption on Autâ€‹(X,L)Autğ‘‹ğ¿\mathrm{Aut}(X,L) [4]. The quantization method is a powerful tool in the study of cscK metrics [4, 5], and it is natural to extend it to the situation Aut0â€‹(X,L)â‰ 0subscriptAut0ğ‘‹ğ¿0\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L)\neq 0.

Generalisation of this approximation process to extremal metrics has been pioneered by Mabuchi [13, 14, 15, 16]. His approach can be understood in the framework of relative stability [23, 1], which naturally appears in GIT in the presence of non-discrete stabilizers. In the quantization setting, elements of Aut0â€‹(X,L)subscriptAut0ğ‘‹ğ¿\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L) acting on the Chow line of (X,L)ğ‘‹ğ¿(X,L) are an obstruction to Chow stability [14, 16, 7]. This obstruction is a source of examples of cscK manifolds that are not asymptotically Chow stable [3, 17]. It is then natural to consider a stability notion relatively to a maximal torus of symmetries TâŠ‚Aut0â€‹(X,L)ğ‘‡subscriptAut0ğ‘‹ğ¿T\subset\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L), so-called Chow polystability relative to Tğ‘‡T [15, 1].

Since then, other notions of quantization of extremal metrics have been introduced. Extremal metrics can be seen as self-similar solutions to the Calabi flow. As noticed by Sano, it is also natural to consider Donaldsonâ€™s iteration process [4] as a discretisation of the Calabi flow. The notion of Ïƒğœ\sigma-balanced metrics, for ÏƒâˆˆAut0â€‹(X,L)ğœsubscriptAut0ğ‘‹ğ¿\sigma\in\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L), provides a quantization of extremal metrics by self-similar solutions to Donalsdonâ€™s iteration process [20]. The Ïƒğœ\sigma-balanced metrics appear as zeros of a finite dimensional moment map, and can be used to recover minimization properties, unicity or splitting results for extremal metrics [21, 22]. Another point of view is given by Hashimoto, whose defined a quantization of the extremal vector field [8]. We refer to [9] for a good reference on these different notions of quantization.

In this note, we show that Mabuchiâ€™s relatively balanced metrics and Sanoâ€™s Ïƒğœ\sigma-balanced metrics are equivalent, for a suitable choice of Ïƒğœ\sigma. In fact, for a given maximal compact torus TâŠ‚Aut0â€‹(X,L)ğ‘‡subscriptAut0ğ‘‹ğ¿T\subset\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L), there is a unique ÏƒâˆˆTcğœsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘\sigma\in T^{c} (modulo Tğ‘‡T) allowing the existence of a Ïƒğœ\sigma-balanced metric. Such an automophism Ïƒğœ\sigma will be called an optimal weight.

Theorem 1.1.

Let (X,L)ğ‘‹ğ¿(X,L) be a polarized compact KÃ¤hler manifold and let TâŠ‚Aut0â€‹(X,L)ğ‘‡subscriptAut0ğ‘‹ğ¿T\subset\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L) be a maximal compact torus. Then (X,L)ğ‘‹ğ¿(X,L) is Chow polystable relative to Tğ‘‡T if and only if it admits a Ïƒğœ\sigma-balanced embedding with ÏƒâˆˆTcğœsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘\sigma\in T^{c} optimal weight.

The paper is organized as follows. Section 2 is a brief review on Chow stability, in relation to balanced embeddings. We introduce necessary notations, definitions and results. In section 3, we define the relative Chow scheme ğ’â€‹â„‹â€‹ğ’ªâ€‹ğ’²NTâ€‹(n,d)ğ’â„‹ğ’ªsuperscriptsubscriptğ’²ğ‘ğ‘‡ğ‘›ğ‘‘\mathcal{CHOW}_{N}^{T}(n,d). Restricting to the smooth case, ğ’â€‹â„‹â€‹ğ’ªâ€‹ğ’²NTâ€‹(n,d)ğ’â„‹ğ’ªsuperscriptsubscriptğ’²ğ‘ğ‘‡ğ‘›ğ‘‘\mathcal{CHOW}_{N}^{T}(n,d) parametrizes Tcsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T^{c}-invariant subvarieties of â„‚â€‹â„™Nâ„‚superscriptâ„™ğ‘\mathbb{C}\mathbb{P}^{N} of degree dğ‘‘d and dimension nğ‘›n, for Tcsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T^{c} a given subtorus of Autâ€‹(â„‚â€‹â„™N)Autâ„‚superscriptâ„™ğ‘\mathrm{Aut}(\mathbb{C}\mathbb{P}^{N}). It provides the natural framework for relative Chow stability. We then prove Theorem 1.1 in Section 4. Along the way, we explain how an optimal weight Ïƒğœ\sigma twists the torus of symmetries Tğ‘‡T to another torus TÏƒsuperscriptğ‘‡ğœT^{\sigma} so that the Chow line of (X,L)ğ‘‹ğ¿(X,L) becomes TÏƒsuperscriptğ‘‡ğœT^{\sigma}-invariant. Finally, we give a closed formula relating the optimal weight Ïƒğœ\sigma to the Tğ‘‡T-character acting on the Chow line of (X,L)ğ‘‹ğ¿(X,L) in Section 4.3.

Remark 2.6.

The character â„±â„±\mathcal{F} is a quantization of the celebrated Futaki character [6].

By definition, the existence of a balanced embedding imposes the vanishing of â„±â„±\mathcal{F}. For any Î¾âˆˆğ”¤ğ¬ğœ‰subscriptğ”¤ğ¬\xi\in\mathfrak{g}_{\bf s}, XÎ¾subscriptğ‘‹ğœ‰X_{\xi} and its lift XÎ¾hsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğœ‰â„X_{\xi}^{h} vanish at ğ¬ğ¬{\bf s}. However, if <Î¼0(ğ¬),Î¾><\mu_{0}({\bf s}),\xi> is not zero, the orbit of a lift xâˆˆâ„’ğ¬ğ‘¥subscriptâ„’ğ¬x\in\mathcal{L}_{\bf s} under the Gğ¬csuperscriptsubscriptğºğ¬ğ‘G_{\bf s}^{c}-action will contain zero, and the Gcsuperscriptğºğ‘G^{c}-orbit will not be closed. To overcome this issue, following SzÃ©kelyhidi [23], one considers a relative notion of stability. In the next section, we introduce a relative Chow scheme and the associated notion of stability.

Remark 4.9.

Note that from Proposition 4.8, the extremal vector Î±Ïƒsuperscriptğ›¼ğœ\alpha^{\sigma} only depends on the connected component of ğ’â€‹â„‹â€‹ğ’ªâ€‹ğ’²NTâ€‹(n,d)ğ’â„‹ğ’ªsubscriptsuperscriptğ’²ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘‘\mathcal{CHOW}^{T}_{N}(n,d) where the Chow line of (X,L)ğ‘‹ğ¿(X,L) lies. In particular, it is invariant under embedded Tğ‘‡T-equivariant complex deformations of (X,L)ğ‘‹ğ¿(X,L). Considering tensor powers Lksuperscriptğ¿ğ‘˜L^{k} of Lğ¿L, and letting kğ‘˜k go to infinity, the extremal vectors Î±Ïƒksuperscriptğ›¼subscriptğœğ‘˜\alpha^{\sigma_{k}} converge to the extremal vector field of (X,L)ğ‘‹ğ¿(X,L) with respect to Tğ‘‡T (see [22]). One recovers the fact that the extremal vector field is invariant under polarized Tğ‘‡T-equivariant complex deformations [11].
